A theoretical investigation on the influence of anatase support and vanadia dispersion on the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propene Yu-Jue Du Zhen Hua Li ⁎ Kang-Nian Fan ⁎ Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Handan Road 220, Shanghai, 200433, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University Handan Road 220 Shanghai 200433 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 21 65643792. Graphical abstract First principle calculations on the ODP reaction catalyzed by VO x /TiO2 indicate that the catalytic activity is related with support surface, vanadia loading and active sites by affecting the oxidizability and bonding ability of active sites. The coexistence of OV= and OV–Ti sites enhances the catalytic activity. The oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODP) on the anatase supported vanadia catalysts (VO x /TiO2) have been investigated using periodic DFT calculations. Free energy profiles indicate that the first C–H activation step is the rate-determining (RD) step and the transition state (TS) of the propene formation step is the RD–TS. ODP activity can be tuned by vanadia dispersion and support surface via the modification of the electronic structure of the active oxygen sites. For the RD step, on both dimer VO x /TiO2 catalysts terminal sites have higher activity. On monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) terminal and interface sites exhibit similar activity, while on monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) interface sites have higher activity. With increasing vanadia loading, the formation of propene changes from propyl radical mechanism to a concerted propoxide one. The results suggest that TiO2 (100) is a better support surface. Terminal and interface oxygen sites act cooperatively as the first and second C–H bond activation centers, respectively. Keywords DFT VO x /TiO2 Propane Oxidative dehydrogenation 1 Introduction The catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbon has attracted considerable interest because of its importance to synthesize useful and value-added chemicals as alkenes and to reduce environmental pollution. Propene is the basic raw material of petrochemical industry and its worldwide demand is growing every year [1–3]. According to NEXANT the demand for propene is expected to grow at almost 5 percent annually [4]. Currently, direct dehydrogenation of propane (DDP) is a main route to produce propene. It is an endothermic and energy intensive process which requires relatively high temperatures to reach a high yield of propene. However, increasing temperatures would favor deep cracking of propane to carbon deposition and lead to decrease of the product yields. In contrast, the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODP) has many advantages. One major advantage of ODP reactions is that it is exothermic and thermodynamically favored even at low temperatures because of the formation of water, which would reduce the formation of coke and extend the lifetime of catalysts [5,6]. Supported vanadia catalysts, which have been widely employed as effective catalysts of important oxidation reactions [7–17], such as the oxidation of methanol, methane and olefins, and the selective catalytic reduction of NO, are among the best catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes [18,19]. The advantages of supported metal oxides as catalysts include higher mechanical strength, better thermal stability and larger surface area. In the past decades, ODP reactions over vanadium-based catalysts have been extensively studied in order to improve the selectivity and yield of alkene. It was found that the activity of catalyst was greatly affected by the loadings of vanadia. At low loadings, vanadia tend to form monovanadates and polyvanadates [20–22], which make the main contribution to the activity of the catalyst. The activity of the catalyst decreases with the surface density of vanadia under high oxygen pressure [20] while increases under relatively low oxygen pressure [17]. A few investigations also focused on the mechanism of the reaction [7,8,11,14]. The redox Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [2,23,24] is the widely accepted mechanism in which the reaction proceeds via the following two major steps: (i) the reduction of the oxide surface by hydrocarbon and (ii) the subsequent fast reoxidation of the surface by the gas-phase oxygen. The first step of the propane oxidation reactions seems to involve the C–H activation step, which is regarded as the rate-determining step. It was also found that propane conversion and propene selectivity are often inversely related [25,26]. Generally, the activity and selectivity of the catalyst depends on its reducibility and basicity [27]. The interface oxygen site of V–O-support was suggested to be the active center of the C–H activation while the bridging oxygen site of the V–O–V species in the polyvanadates can decrease the activity and selectivity of ODP reaction [14,20–22,28]. Several groups have already studied the reaction mechanism of selective hydrocarbon oxidation on vanadium-based catalysts [18,24,29–41]. Fu et al. studied the ODP on the V2O5 (001) surface [24], they found that the active oxygen site for the first C–H activation is the terminal O(1) site. On the other hand, the active site for the second C–H activation to form propene is the two-fold coordinated O(2) site rather than the O(1) site due to the high stability of the propoxide species formed on the O(1) site. It was found that the first C–H activation follows a radical mechanism and is the rate-determining step. Dai et al. [39] investigated the deep oxidation of propane to CO2 and H2O based on the same catalyst model employed by Fu et al. They found that the O(1) site could facilely oxidize acetone and propene into CO2 while the bridging oxygen site O(2) is inert for both side reactions. They suggested that the preparation of catalysts with highly dispersed V2O5 species is desirable to achieve high propene selectivity for the ODP reaction. Recently, Alexopoulos et al. have studied the ODP reaction mechanism on V2O5 (001) and a monolayer V2O5 supported on the anatase TiO2 (001) surface [38]. They found that the TiO2 support lowers the energy barrier for the C–H bond activation and the O(1) site is the most active site. Sauer and coworkers have studied the ODP reaction mechanism on the silica supported monomeric VO x employing a cluster model [29]. They found that the first C–H bond activation occurs exclusively on the terminal oxygen sites (O=V) while the second C–H bond activation to produce propene can also occur on the interface oxygen sites (V–O–Si). Although previous studies have already provided useful information about the ODP reaction on vanadium-based catalysts, a systematic investigation on the effects of catalyst dispersion and support surface is still necessary. The models employed by previous studies focus only on some types of oxygen sites of the supported VO x catalysts. For example, there are no interface oxygen sites on the monolayer V2O5/TiO2 catalyst while no bridging oxygen sites on the monomer VO x /SiO2 catalyst. It is expected that the activity of vanadia supported on metal oxide can be tuned by controlling the polymerization extent and the support surface. The reaction mechanisms involved and the factors responsible for the higher reactivity and selectivity of the supported V2O5 catalysts still remain unsolved. In this paper, we present a detailed periodic DFT study on the ODP reaction over the VO x /TiO2 (anatase) catalysts. Monomer and dimer VO x species were supported on two common surfaces of anatase, namely the (001) and (100) surfaces. The model VO x /TiO2 (anatase) catalysts studied include three types of oxygen sites: the terminal OV= sites, the interface OV–Ti sites, and the bridging OV–V sites. The goal of this study is to assess the activity of the different oxygen sites of the supported vanadia catalyst, dispersion effect of vanadia, the effect of the support anatase surface, and to obtain a quantitative insight into the reaction mechanism. 2 Computational details All total energy density functional theory calculations were carried out using the SIESTA package with numerical atomic orbital basis sets and Troullier–Martins norm-conserving pseudopotentials [42,43]. The exchange-correlation functional utilized is the generalized gradient approximation method, known as GGA–PBE [44]. A double-ζ plus polarization (DZP) basis set was employed. The orbital-confining cutoff radii were determined from an energy shift of 0.01eV. The DZP basis set and the pseudo-potentials have already been justified in our previous studies [39,45], which indicate that the basis set used here have reasonable accuracy to provide reliable energetic results. The L-BFGS method [46] was employed for locating energy minima until the Cartesian forces on the relaxed atoms were all less than 0.05eVÅ−1. The vanadia species supported on (001) and (100) anatase surfaces were routinely modeled by a four-atomic-layer slab with top two layers allowed to relax. A (3×3) super cell and a (3×1) super cell was adopted for the periodically repeated (001) slab and (100) slab and the vacuum separation between slabs was set to more than 15Å. The energy cutoff for the real space grid used to represent the density was set as 150Ry. Only Γ-point was used to sample the Brillouin zone in our calculations due to the large lattice parameter. Spin polarization was considered during all the calculations. To validate the choice of method and various parameters such as energy cutoff, the number of k-points and dipole correction, the energy barrier of the first C–H activation step on the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface had been chosen as a test case. Two energy cutoffs of 200Ry and 250Ry had been tested. The difference in the calculated energy barrier with respect to that calculated with 150Ry is less than 0.07eV. To test the convergence with respect to the number of k-points, 3×3×1 and 4×4×1 k-points had been applied. It was found that the energy barrier converges beyond 3×3×1 k-points and the error in the energy barrier calculated with only Γ-point is below 0.1eV. Therefore sampling the Brillouin zone with only Γ-point is adequate enough. Since the TiO2 surface is not symmetric and with non-zero dipole moment, a dipole correction was considered and it turned out that the correction has no effect on the energetic results at all. Detailed validation results are tabulated in Table S1 of the Supplementary material. A modified dimer method was employed to search the transition state (TS) on the potential energy surface [47,48]. Since the reaction network is very complicated, it is too expensive to perform numerical vibrational analyses for all the stationary points located in the present study. Therefore, harmonic vibrational analyses were performed only for some key stationary points (the stationary points of the two lowest-energy pathways) to calculate zero-point vibrational energy (ZPE) correction and to confirm if a TS is the desired TS to connect the initial state and the final state of an elementary reaction step. A two-point numerical evaluation of the Cartesian force constants for all the atoms was performed with a step size of 0.0025Å. The vibrational modes contributed from the fixed bulk lattice atoms were removed by setting their atomic weights to be arbitrarily very large values so that the wavenumbers of these vibrational modes are close to zero. All the other TSs were confirmed by changing the geometry slightly toward the initial state or the final state and then doing a full geometry optimization. This is a method similar to the IRC calculation (it is worth mentioning here that IRC analysis has not been implemented in most periodic software codes yet.). Energy barrier of an elementary reaction step is determined as the energy difference between the saddle point and the initial state. The adsorption energy (E ads) is calculated as (1) E ads = ( E adsorbate-substrate ) − ( E adsorbate + E substrate ) where a negative E ads indicates exoergic process. 3 Results and discussion In the present work, the ODP reaction mechanism over four model VO x /TiO2 catalysts, namely monomer VO x /TiO2 (001), dimer VO x /TiO2 (001), monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) and dimer VO x /TiO2 (100), has been investigated. The structures of the two supported monomeric VO x catalysts are based on our previous work [45]. Furthermore, we have optimized the most stable dimerically dispersed structures of VO x on the two support anatase surfaces (Fig. 1 ). Calatayud et al. [49–51] have investigated both monomeric and dimeric vanadia species deposited on anatase TiO2 by using periodic models. The formal oxidation state of vanadium atom of the initial catalysts is +5. In our models, the adsorbed vanadia species can be described as HVO3, V2O5, H3VO4, and H4V2O7, whose hydrogen atoms are adsorbed on the oxygen sites of the TiO2 surface. The reaction energies of the following four reactions were used to characterize the stability of the four VO x /TiO2 catalysts, respectively: • Monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface: H3VO4 +slab→HVO3/slab+H2O • Dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface: 2H3VO4 +slab→V2O5/slab+3H2O • Monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface: H3VO4 +slab→H3VO4/slab • Dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface: 2H3VO4 +slab→H4V2O7/slab+H2O Considering the changes of oxidation state of vanadium atom along the reaction coordinate, we have selected the key transition state of the first C–H activation step and the reduced catalyst caused by H2O desorption on the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface and tested the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic possibilities of vanadium atoms (see Tables S2 and S3 of the Supplementary material.. The results show that for both structures, the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic states have the same energy (ΔE <0.01eV). This is expected since the supercell utilized is large. 3.1 Physical adsorption of propane We have first examined the physical adsorption of propane at the various oxygen sites on the VO x /TiO2 (001) surface. It turns out that the most stable adsorption structure is the adsorption at the interface OV–Ti with an adsorption energy of −3.8kcalmol−1 for the monomer structure and at the bridging OV–V site with an adsorption energy of −3.0kcalmol−1 for the dimer structure, respectively. The results indicate that propane undergoes preliminary weak physical adsorption on the surface prior to dissociation, which is consistent with previous theoretical studies on the ODP reaction on the V2O5 (001) surface [24,38] and on the Ga2O3 (100) surface [52]. Considering that the reaction occurs at high temperature, e.g. 800K, gas-phase propane is more stable than it is on the surface due to its large entropy (see also the discussion in Section 4.4). This is in accordance with the FTIR study of Busca and coworkers that no physically adsorbed propane can be detected in the experiment [53,54]. Therefore, although the adsorption energy of propane calculated by the PBE functional is not very accurate due to basis set superstition error [55] and the deficiency of the PBE functional in dealing with long range weak interactions [38], the physical adsorption state of propane is kinetically unimportant under the experimental conditions of the ODP reaction. 3.2 C–H bond activation and propene formation The C–H bond in either methyl or methylene group of propane can be broken with the formation of n-propoxide or i-propoxide on the surface, respectively. It is well-known from thermodynamics that the C–H bond in the methyl group is much stronger than that in the methylene group. Experimental results indicated that methylene C–H bond cleavage is more feasible than methyl C–H bond cleavage [33,56]. Several theoretical studies also showed that the activation of C–H bond in the methylene group is both thermodynamically and kinetically favored than that in the methyl group [24,38,57,58]. Therefore, in the present work we also focus on the breaking of the C–H bond in the methylene group. Other channels such as the breaking of C–C bond has to overcome very high energy barriers [38] and therefore will not be considered in the present study. Two mechanisms have been proposed regarding to the activation of the C–H bond [57,59]. One is the heterolytic splitting of the C–H bond, leading to an alkyl anion and a proton. Another one is homolytic cleavage that usually takes place on surface oxygen sites. Previous work has shown that homolytic cleavage of the C–H bond of propane is energetically more feasible [24]. Based on our previous works on the ODP and DDP reactions [24,52], we considered only the most possible radical mechanism, for the first C–H bond activation process (Fig. 2 ), for which a lattice oxygen atom abstracts a H atom directly from propane, involving 2e in the process. Subsequently, the propyl radical either desorbs into gas phase or rebinds to an adjacent oxygen site to form an i-propoxide species. While for the second C–H bond breaking process, namely the propene formation process (C3H7 →C3H6 +H, Fig. 2), we investigated two possible mechanisms. One is a radical mechanism (i.e. propyl mechanism), and the other one is a concerted mechanism (i.e. propoxide mechanism). In the propoxide mechanism, starting from the adsorbed i-propoxide intermediate, the cleavage of C–O bond and H abstraction by a nearby active O site take place simultaneously. This pathway features a cyclic TS, involving 4e in the process [57]. On the monomer VO x /TiO2 surfaces, there are two different types of available active O sites (Fig. 1), namely terminal OV= site and interface OV–Ti site. Therefore, the ODP reaction could result in five product combinations. To make the discussion concise, the combination of oxygen sites can be denoted as OA–OB, i.e. OV=–OV–Ti, OV=–O(H)V=, OV–Ti–OV=, OV–Ti–OV–Ti, OV–Ti–O(H)V–Ti, where OA denotes the O site to abstract a H atom from propane to form a propyl radical or an i-propoxide species, OB represents the O site to whom propyl or i-propoxide leaves a H atom to form propene. It should be mentioned that O(H)V= and O(H)V–Ti represent the oxygen species of the hydroxyl groups formed from the first C–H bond breaking on the OV= and OV–Ti sites, respectively. Similarly, on the dimer VO x /TiO2 surfaces in addition to OV= and OV–Ti there is one additional oxygen site called bridging OV–V site (Fig. 1). It is then expected that ten combinations in total are possible for the reaction on the dimer VO x /TiO2 surfaces, i.e. OV=–OV=, OV=–O(H)V=, OV=–OV–Ti, OV=–OV–V, OV–Ti–OV=, OV–Ti–OV–Ti, OV–Ti–O(H)V–Ti, OV–Ti–OV–V, OV–V–OV=, OV–V–OV–Ti. It is noteworthy that for the propene formation process, there are two types of OV–Ti on each dimer catalyst due to the subtle chemical environmental difference caused by the adsorbed H from the first C–H activation step (either on OV= or on OV–Ti): OV–Ti on the same or neighboring VO x entity of the adsorbed H. Similarly there are two types of OV= for the propene formation step if the first H is on OV–Ti. However, our calculations show that the energy barriers for the propene formation step on the OV–Ti or OV= site on the same or neighboring VO x entity turn out to differ by less than 0.05eV. Therefore, they can be treated as equivalent. The results reported and discussed later are all on the active sites of the neighboring VO x entity. 3.3 Monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface 3.3.1 OV–Ti–OV–Ti, OV–Ti–OV= and OV–Ti–O(H)V–Ti The OV–Ti–OV=, OV–Ti–OV–Ti and OV–Ti–O(H)V= pathways share the same initial step, namely, H abstraction from the methylene group of propane by OV–Ti, where the C–H bond is activated via TS1 (Fig. 3 ). The energy barrier is calculated to be 36.5kcalmol−1, and the physically adsorbed propyl radical intermediate (IM1) is only 3.6kcalmol−1 more stable than TS1. IM2 is the state that the propyl radical desorbs from the surface into the gas phase. IM3−1 and IM3−2 are the other two physically adsorption states of the propyl radical on the other oxygen sites of the surface. The results indicate that the first C–H bond of propane is activated through a radical mechanism, which is accordant with previous DFT studies on the Ga2O3-catalyzed propane dehydrogenation [52] and on the MoO3-catalyzed light alkane dehydrogenation [57,60]. However, previous study on the propane activation on the V2O5 (001) surface [24] indicated that an oxo-insertion mechanism, that is, a lattice oxygen atom inserts into the C–H bond of propane forming an alcoholic intermediate and then the proton of the alcoholic group transfers to the nearby lattice oxygen, is energetically preferred. We have also investigated this mechanism and have optimized a TS in which the H–OV–Ti bond length is 0.99Å, Cpropyl–OV–Ti distance is 2.20Å, Cpropyl–H length is 2.57Å and meanwhile the V–O(H)V–Ti bond is already ruptured with a bond length of 2.30Å. We then further examined this TS by changing the geometry slightly toward the reactants and then doing a full geometry optimization. The optimization ended up with a physically adsorbed propyl radical, not the physically adsorbed propane which is expected for an oxo-insertion mechanism. Thus, on the supported vanadia catalysts this transition state of the oxo-insertion mechanism is not really the TS connecting the physically adsorbed propane reactant and the alcoholic intermediate, but the TS of propyl radical forming C–O bond with the oxygen of the hydroxyl group. Next, we investigated the propene formation process. To form propene, the propyl radical generated from the C–H bond activation of propane must release a H atom, and the resulting propene then desorbs from the surface. The H atom of the propyl radical can be abstracted either by the adjacent OV–Ti or by the terminal OV= or by the newly formed O(H)V–Ti site. From Fig. 3 it can be found that the formation of propene on the nearby OV–Ti site is slightly more favored than that on the OV= site, with an energy barrier of 7.5kcalmol−1 (TS2−1). While the energy barrier for the pathway involving O(H)V–Ti is much higher with an energy barrier of 16.4kcalmol−1 (TS2−3). After TS2−1, the obtained propene then desorbs to the gas phase, leaving two H atoms on the surface to form two hydroxyl groups. The whole process is endoergic with a reaction energy of 23.4kcalmol−1. The high energy of TS2−3 may be due to the surface reconstruction caused by the elongation of the V–O(H) bond, which elongates from 1.95Å in the reactant to 2.34Å in the TS structure. This elongation is caused by the reduction of OV–Ti by the two abstracted hydrogen atoms, which decreases the ability of the oxygen atom to form covalent bond with Ti and V atoms. Alternatively, the propyl radical can also form chemical bond with the nearby interface O atoms (OV–Ti), through TS′−1 with an energy barrier of 7.5kcalmol−1. Formation of the chemically adsorbed i-propoxide intermediate IM3−3 is 2.9kcalmol−1 endoergic with respect to the propane reactant. Starting from i-propoxide on the OV–Ti site, propene can be generated via a propoxide mechanism by the cleavage of C–O bond and H migration to a nearby lattice O site simultaneously. After exploring all the possible reaction pathways, it was found that the most favorable pathway of H abstraction utilizes a nearby OV–Ti, with an energy barrier of 39.7kcalmol−1 (TS2−4). Although the propyl radical can also chemically adsorb on the newly formed surface OH group to form propanol, previous and the present calculation results indicate that the formation of propanol is both thermodynamically and kinetically unfavorable compared to the formation of propoxide [38,39]. Even if propanol is formed, the transformation of propanol to the more stable propoxide by hydrogen transfer from the OH of propanol to the nearby oxygen site only needs to overcome an energy barrier of just a few kcalmol−1 [38,39]. Therefore, the pathways via the propanol intermediate will not be considered in the present study. Considering that the ODP reaction is carried out at high temperatures, the significant entropy loss of propane on going from gas phase to the TS on the surface should not be ignored. Consequently, it will greatly stabilize the reactant state (see also the discussion in Section 4.4). Therefore, the unstable intermediates (including IM3−3) can be treated with the steady-state approximation, and it shows that the overall energy barrier of a pathway is determined by relative energy of the highest-energy TS to the initial reactants. Thus, the overall energy barrier is 42.2kcalmol−1 and 42.6kcalmol−1 for the OV–Ti–OV–Ti radical pathway and the OV–Ti–OV–Ti propoxide pathway, respectively. Therefore, for the C–H bond activation by the OV–Ti site of the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface, the possibility of propene formation on OV–Ti via the propyl mechanism is similar to that via the propoxide mechanism. 3.3.2 OV=–OV–Ti and OV=–O(H)V= Besides OV–Ti, the activation of C–H bond of propane can also occur on OV=. The energy profiles of the most feasible pathways together with the TS structures are shown in Fig. 4 . The first C–H bond activation of propane is 37.8kcalmol−1 endoergic with an energy barrier of 40.7kcalmol−1 (TS3), which is 4.2kcalmol−1 higher than that on the OV–Ti site. IM4 is the propyl radical physically adsorbing on the newly generated hydroxyl group. The corresponding gas-phase propyl radical intermediate (IM5) is 47.8kcalmol−1 higher in energy than the initial reactants. To form propene, the two pathways of H abstraction directly from the physically adsorbed propyl radical IM6−1 and IM6−2 by a nearby OV–Ti and the newly generated O(H)V= have similar energy barriers, which are 7.8kcalmol−1 and 8.2kcalmol−1, respectively. On the other hand, propyl radical can first form a stable i-propoxide intermediate (IM6−3) with a nearby OV–Ti, then IM6−3 transfers a methyl H atom to another OV–Ti, with an energy barrier of 40.6kcalmol−1. Based on the same arguments in Section 3.3.1, the overall energy barrier of this pathway is 54.6kcalmol−1, similar to that of the propyl mechanism (53.3kcalmol−1). Therefore, for the C–H activation on the OV= site of the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface, the possibility of propene formation on the OV–Ti via propyl mechanism is similar to that via propoxide mechanism. With all the results above, it can be concluded that the OV–Ti site is more active than the OV= site for the first C–H bond activation. The higher reactivity of OV–Ti than OV= has been discussed in our previous work, where we found that the OV–Ti site is better nucleophilic center to adopt protons than the OV= site [45]. Moreover, for the propene formation step, it is comparatively facile on the OV–Ti site both via propyl mechanism and via propoxide mechanism. Considering that the migration of propyl radical on the surface is from one physically adsorbed state to another and the potential energy surface is always quite flat, it is hard to locate the corresponding migration TS. Furthermore, gas-phase propyl radical (IM2 or IM5) is actually more stable than the physically adsorbed propyl radical (IM1 and IM3 or IM4 and IM6, respectively) due to its large entropy. Therefore, the migration can also follow a desorption and re-adsorption mechanism [29]. Since the migration of the physically adsorbed propyl radical is facile and quick, by applying the steady-state approximation, it shows that the energy of the propyl radical will not appear in the expression of the overall rate constant, and thus is actually kinetically unimportant. To make the discussion concise and the energy-profile plots neat, they have been omitted from the energy-profile plots of other reaction pathways and will not be discussed in the following sections. The reader may refer to the Supplementary material for the energy-profile plots with complete details. 3.4 Dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface Next, we investigate the ODP reaction pathways on the dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface. On the dimer surface, as mentioned above, there are three types of oxygen sites involved (Fig. 1). There is one more oxygen site called bridging oxygen (OV–V) in addition to OV= and OV–Ti. Similarly, according to the types of oxygen sites bonding with the two abstracted hydrogen atoms, there are ten product combinations in total, i.e. OV=–OV=, OV=–OV–Ti, OV=–OV–V, OV=–O(H)V=, OV–Ti–OV=, OV–Ti–OV–Ti, OV–Ti–OV–V, OV–Ti–O(H)V–Ti, OV–V–OV= and OV–V–OV–Ti. 3.4.1 OV=–OV=, OV=–O(H)V=, OV=–OV–Ti and OV=–OV–V The energy profiles of the pathways and some selected TS structures are depicted in Fig. 5 . The initial step of all three pathways is H abstraction by the same OV= site resulting a physically adsorbed propyl radical and its energy barrier is 37.4kcalmol−1. Then the physically adsorbed radical may lose a H atom to all the possible active oxygen sites, i.e. OV–Ti, OV=, O(H)V= and OV–V sites. Here and afterwards only the results for the most feasible pathways through either the propyl mechanism or the propoxide mechanism are presented and discussed. Detailed energy-profile plots for other less feasible pathways are available in the supplementary material for reference. The results show that the second hydrogen abstraction by OV–Ti is slightly more favorable than the other three oxygen sites with an energy barrier of 14.9kcalmol−1. The overall energy barriers of forming propene from propyl via radical mechanism on different sites are close to each other, which are around 50kcalmol−1. For the propene formation via the propoxide mechanism, the TS to form i-propoxide from propyl could not be located by all means. A relaxed scanning of the potential energy surface by gradually shortening the forming C–O bond while relaxing all other geometry parameters shows that the potential energy surface at long C–O bond distance is quite flat (see Fig. S1 of the Supplementary material. As a result, this TS is hard to locate and even if there is a TS its energy would be very close to that of IM7. Therefore, this TS is omitted in Fig. 5. The energetic results indicate that propyl radical prefers to form bond with another OV= site since forming the HOV= +C3H7OV= product combination is strongly exoergic by 35.4kcalmol−1 from gas-phase propyl radical, while the HOV= +C3H7OV–Ti and HOV= +C3H7OV–V product combinations (omitted in Fig. 5) are 21.1kcalmol−1 and 20.1kcalmol−1 exoergic, respectively. Then the formed C3H7OV= intermediate will lose one methyl hydrogen to a nearby OV–Ti site and simultaneously break the C–O bond to produce propene. This process is endoergic by 24.3kcalmol−1 with an energy barrier of 38.2kcalmol−1. Based on the similar arguments in Section 3.3, IM8 can be treated as an unstable intermediate and by applying the steady-state approximation the TS of the propene formation step is supposed to be the rate-determining TS [61] in the whole reaction pathway. The overall energy barrier of the propoxide pathway is then determined to be 46.6kcalmol−1 and is 3.4kcalmol−1 lower than that of the lowest-energy pathway via the propyl mechanism. 3.4.2 OV–Ti–OV=, OV–Ti–OV–Ti, OV–Ti–OV–V and OV–Ti–O(H)V–Ti The whole pathways of the ODP on the OV–Ti site are similar to those on the OV= site except that the relative energies of the TSs located are shifted to higher energies (Fig. 6 ). The energy barrier of the first C–H bond activation is 42.3kcalmol−1. To form propene, losing a methyl H from the physically adsorbed propyl to an adjacent OV= is the most energetically favorable pathway for the reaction following the propyl mechanism. For the propoxide mechanism, the physically adsorbed propyl radical firstly becomes chemically adsorbed as C3H7OV= (IM10), which is the most stable propoxide intermediate, then C3H7OV= loses a methyl H atom to an adjacent OV–Ti to form propene through TS8−2. This process is endoergic by 26.2kcalmol−1 with an energy barrier of 37.5kcalmol−1. The overall barrier of this pathway is 3.4kcalmol−1 lower than that of the OV–Ti–OV= channel through the propyl mechanism. 3.4.3 OV–V–OV= and OV–V–OV–Ti The energy profiles of the ODP reaction on the OV–V site are similar to those on the OV= and OV–Ti sites except that the relative energies of the TSs located are lifted to even higher energies (Fig. 7 ). The energy barrier of the first C–H bond activation is 46.6kcalmol−1. Propene formation through methyl H abstraction from the physically adsorbed propyl radical by OV= has a lower energy barrier than that by OV–Ti. Alternatively, propyl radical can migrate to the nearby OV= to form the most energetically favored i-propoxide intermediate IM12, i.e. HOV–V +C3H7OV=, through TS′−3. Starting from IM12, the second H abstraction to form the propene product is activated by an adjacent OV–Ti site with an energy barrier of 42.4kcalmol−1. The overall energy barrier of this propoxide pathway is similar to that of the most favorable pathway of the propyl mechanism. Summarizing the above results, the most feasible pathway for the ODP reaction on the dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface is that the first C–H activation takes place on the OV= site and propene is generated through C3H7OV= losing a methyl hydrogen to the other OV–Ti site via the propoxide mechanism. 3.5 Monomer and dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface On the VO x /TiO2 (100) surface similar energy-profile plots have been obtained and only a few low-energy pathways are shown in Figs. 8 and 9 for the monomer and dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface, respectively. Detailed description of the reaction processes and energy-profile plots is available in the Supplementary material for reference. Here the results for the VO x /TiO2 (100) surface will just be briefly discussed. 3.5.1 Monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface From Fig. 8 it can be concluded that on the monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface the ODP reaction can either follow the OV=–OV–Ti pathway by the propyl mechanism or the OV–Ti–OV–Ti pathway by the propoxide mechanism since both pathways have a similar overall energy barrier of 43kcalmol−1. 3.5.2 Dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface As can be seen from Fig. 9, on the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface, regardless of the oxygen site the first C–H activation step takes place on, the propene formation step always prefer on the OV–Ti site following the propoxide mechanism. Meanwhile, it can be concluded that the pathway through OV=–OV–Ti by the propoxide mechanism is the most energetically feasible pathway on all four VO x /TiO2 surfaces. 3.6 Water formation To complete the catalytic cycle, the two H atoms abstracted from propane must eventually leave the surface in the form of H2O. Water is produced by the generated two adjacent hydroxyl groups through a coupling reaction. The optimized structures and the energy profiles of the water formation on the four VO x /TiO2 surfaces are shown in Fig. 10 . Since these four surfaces follow similar pathways, only the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface is discussed in detail (Fig. 10(a)). As H atom binding with the OV= site is stronger than that with the OV–Ti site, O(H)V=–O(H)V= coupling is the most likely pathway. At the initial state, the two hydrogen atoms are on the OV–Ti and OV= sites, respectively. Subsequent migration of hydrogen to the same terminal O site is endoergic by 13.7kcalmol−1. Considering that the migration of H atom on the surface is quite complicated and this process is relatively facile comparing to the oxidation of propane, there is no much necessary to search the TS of H atom migration between two surface oxygen sites. The overall energy needed to produce gas-phase H2O is calculated to be 29.4kcalmol−1. We have also tried to optimize a structure in which both two H atoms bond to the OV–Ti site but failed to locate the corresponding structure. After H2O desorption, the vanadium atom relaxes a bit inward to the anatase surface and the system has a net spin of 1.43e, implying that the vanadium atom is reduced and has unpaired electrons. At the presence of O2, the reoxidation is quite facile and it is not the rate-determining step of the ODP reaction on the V2O5/ZrO2 [56]. It is noteworthy that the reoxidation time scales may be prominent on different support. This process will not be studied here since it is beyond the scope of our work. It is noteworthy that the final state will actually be greatly stabilized due to the large translational entropy of H2O (about the same as propane, 39.5calmol−1 K−1 at 800K) in the gas phase. Thus the overall barrier is still determined by the relative energy of the TS for the propene formation step with respect to the propane reactant. 4 General discussion With all the results presented, a summary on the energetics of the dehydrogenation of propane on the four TiO2 supported VO x catalysts is presented in Table 1 where only the energetics for the most feasible pathways on each catalyst and the corresponding active oxygen sites are shown. It can be seen clearly that the most energetically favored reaction pathway on the four catalysts is the OV=–OV–Ti pathway via the propoxide mechanism on the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface, with the energy barrier of the first C–H activation step being 24.1kcalmol−1 and the overall energy barrier being 27.4kcalmol−1. The vibrational frequencies of the key reaction intermediates of this pathway and the monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface are calculated and the ZPE-corrected energetic results are listed in the brackets in Table 1. It can be seen that the ZPE correction to the energy barrier of the first C–H activation step is more prominent than that to the propene formation step since the C–H bond of propane is stronger than that of propyl radical. However it is expected that each step on different oxygen sites would have similar ZPE correction to the energy barrier. Considering that energetic result may depend on the description of the d electrons of the V atoms, we have performed all the key TSs in Table 1 with the PBE+ U method with U eff =2.0eV for V [62,63] (The PBE+ U calculations were performed with the VASP software package [64,65] with a plane-wave energy cutoff of 400eV). The results are presented in Table S4. The results indicate that the energetic results obtained by PBE+ U do not change the qualitative trends among the four catalysts. In this case, the PBE functional can provide a sound basis for comparative studies since we are interested in trends and simple correlations. Actually, the use of DFT+ U may not always be good since it may introduce additional sources of errors and inaccuracies [66]. In the following discussion, a systematic comparison of active oxygen sites, support anatase surfaces and dispersion of vanadia on the catalytic performance has been made. The rate-determining step, rate-determining states and the reaction mechanism have been discussed. Qualitative trend and general rules can be drawn to give deeper understandings to the ODP reaction. 4.1 Role of active oxygen sites From Table 1 and the discussion above, it can be seen that on the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface, the activation of the first C–H bond of propane on the OV–Ti site is predicted to be more active than that on the OV= site since its energy barrier is lower than the latter by 4.2kcalmol−1. On the monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface OV= and OV–Ti sites exhibit a similar activity toward the first C–H bond activation of propane since the calculated energy barriers are almost the same (31.5kcalmol−1 vs. 31.4kcalmol−1). On the other hand, on both the dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface and (100) surface the C–H bond activation is mainly through the direct H abstraction by the OV= site. For the propene formation step, regardless of the VO x dispersion and the support surface, the active oxygen site is always the interface OV–Ti site. To understand the activities of the different oxygen sites toward the first C–H bond activation which is the rate-determining step of the ODP reaction as discussed later, we have computed the local bonding ability of the oxygen sites using H2 as the probe. The bonding ability is measured by the reaction energy of the H2+2M→2M−H reaction, where M is the oxygen site. Thus more negative reaction energy implies higher bonding ability of the oxygen site. Bell and his coworkers found that the reduction rates of the metal oxides correlate well with their ODP rates [14]. The present computational results show a bonding ability of OV–Ti >OV= (−24.0kcalmol−1 vs. −7.0kcalmol−1) for the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface, OV= >OV–Ti >OV–V (−18.0kcalmol−1 vs. −1.6kcalmol−1 vs. 2.8kcalmol−1) for the dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface, OV= ≈OV–Ti (−29.0kcalmol−1 vs. −28.8kcalmol−1) for the monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface and OV= >OV–Ti >OV–V (−30.8kcalmol−1 vs. −16.2 vs. −14.8kcalmol−1) for the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface. It can be seen that the bonding ability of the oxygen sites is in good accordance with their ability in activating the first C–H bond of propane. In addition, we have performed projected-DOS (p-DOS) analyses to investigate the electronic structures of the four VO x /TiO2 catalysts and the p-DOS plots are shown in Fig. 11 . Bader charge analyses on the oxygen sites for the first C–H activation step have also been performed and the results are listed in Table 2 . Fig. 11 shows that the 2p orbitals of various oxygen sites contribute to the valence band at −6–0eV, while the conduct band is mainly composed of the 3d orbitals of vanadium. Thus, for the ODP reaction the oxygen atoms are the nucleophilic centers to attack the positively charged H atoms and activate the C–H bond. The higher activity of OV–Ti to OV= on the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface during the first H abstraction process can be understood from the electronic properties of the active sites of the catalysts. Fig. 11(a) indicates that the 2p orbitals of the interface OV–Ti atoms are much closer to the Fermi level than the terminal OV= atom, which implies that OV–Ti is a better nucleophilic center and may exhibit higher activity than OV= in the ODP reaction. Besides, OV–Ti has more extended 2p orbitals which implies that OV–Ti has a stronger bonding ability than the terminal oxygen site. The superior activity of OV–Ti on this surface can also be understood from the Bader charge analysis results in Table 2. The values presented in Table 2 are the charge differences (Δq O) of the oxygen sites before and after they abstract a hydrogen atom from propane. Δq O characterizes the ability of the oxygen sites to draw electrons from the abstracted hydrogen atom. A plot of the energy barrier for the first C–H bond activation step vs. Δq O is shown in Fig. 12 . The plot indicates that for the OV= or the OV–Ti site, the more negative Δq O is, the lower the energy barrier is. Thus for the same type of oxygen sites, the C–H activation ability of the oxygen sites can be well characterized by Δq O. Results in Table 2 indicate that Δq O of the OV= site of the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface is least negative (−0.66 e), while Δq O of the OV= sites of the other three catalysts are all more negative. Meanwhile, Δq O of the OV–Ti site of this surface is second most negative among the four OV–Ti sites but they are very close to each other. Therefore, the higher activity of OV–Ti than OV= in abstracting H atom from propane on the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface is mainly due to the lowering of the OV= activity rather than the enhancement of the OV–Ti activity. By comparing the two dimer VO x /TiO2 catalysts from the p-DOS plots in Fig. 11(b) and (d), it can be seen that OV= has more localized 2p orbitals close to the Fermi level than the other two types of oxygen sites. This implies that the OV= sites of the two dimer VO x /TiO2 surfaces are better nucleophilic active centers. On the other hand for the monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface, the valence band closest to the Fermi level is composed of the 2p orbitals of both OV= and OV–Ti sites (Fig. 11(c)), indicating that OV= and OV–Ti have similar nucleophilicity. The present results of the electronic structure property are in good accordance with the different C–H bond activation abilities of the oxygen sites of the four catalysts at the initial stage of the reaction. 4.2 Effect of the anatase surface By comparing the energy barrier of the first C–H activation step and the overall energy barrier of the whole ODP reaction on TiO2 (001) and (100) surfaces presented in Table 1, it can be seen that catalysts supported on the (100) surface show higher activity than those on the (001) surface. This can be understood from the p-DOS plots in Fig. 11. The p-DOS plots show that the center of the valence bands of both the monomer and dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surfaces are closer to the Fermi level than those of the monomer and dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surfaces, which suggests that the oxygen sites on the former two surfaces have higher ability to bond H atoms than the latter two. Moreover, the formation energy of VO x species over the TiO2 surfaces follows the stability sequence of (001)>(100) [45]. Generally, the more stable a structure is, the more inert it will be. Therefore, the support surface has modified the electronic structure of the VO x catalysts and consequently modified the activity of the catalysts. The present results indicate that the anatase (100) surface enhances the bonding ability of the oxygen sites and thus the VO x catalysts supported on the (100) surface exhibit higher activity than those on the (001) surface. 4.3 Effect of vanadia dispersion The energetic results presented in Table 1 indicate that on the dimer dispersed VO x /TiO2 (100) catalyst the overall energy barrier of the ODP reaction is much lower than that on the monomer dispersed VO x /TiO2 (100) catalyst. However, on the anatase (001) surface the ODP reaction catalyzed by the dimer dispersed VO x has to overcome higher energy barrier than that catalyzed by the monomer dispersed VO x . Comparing the p-DOS plots of Fig. 11(a) and (d) (those of the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface and the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface) to Fig. 11(b) and (c) (those of the dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface and the monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface), respectively, it can be found that (a) and (d) have narrower band gaps than (b) and (c), respectively. This indicates that on the TiO2 (001) surface, the oxygen sites of the monomer dispersed VO x are more active than those of the dimer dispersed VO x . On the other hand, on the TiO2 (100) surface the oxygen sites of the dimer dispersed VO x are more active than those of the monomer dispersed VO x . Besides, the p-DOS of the vanadium atoms in both Fig. 11(a) and (d) have more extended 3d orbitals than those in Fig. 11(b) and (c) which implies that these vanadium atoms have stronger bonding ability and can well accommodate extra electrons from the nearby oxygen sites. The delocalization of the extra electrons drawn from the abstracted hydrogen into the whole catalyst system can help to stabilize the reaction TS [67]. Therefore, the two factors mentioned above result in higher activity of the dimer dispersed VO x /TiO2 (100) catalyst than the monomer dispersed one. On the other hand, on the anatase (001) surface the monomer dispersed VO x catalyst shows better activity. Summarizing the discussion above, it can be seen that the support surface and the dispersion of the VO x catalyst have changed the electronic properties of the oxygen sites and consequently changed their activity in activating C–H bond of propane. Qualitative trend on the activity of the catalysts can be obtained by just performing electronic property analyses of the catalyst. In general, with increasing VO x dispersion, the active oxygen site for the first C–H activation step changes from interface OV–Ti site to the terminal OV= site while the active oxygen site for the propene formation step is always the interface OV–Ti site. The bridging OV–V sites which appear in polymeric VO x catalysts and crystal V2O5 catalysts are less active. Therefore a catalyst with better activity should have both OV= and OV–Ti sites presented. According to our previous work about the further and complete oxidation of propane to CO2 based on the V2O5(001) [39], the terminal OV= sites of the V2O5(001) surface are the active sites for the formation of acetone from i-propoxide and the further combustion of acetone. Thus, for the VO x /TiO2 catalysts too high a ratio of terminal oxygen sites will decrease the selectivity of propene, which implies that polymeric VO x will have lower propene selectivity. In addition catalysts with high VO x loading are also less active due to the reduced number of OV–Ti sites and surface VO x units [14]. On the other hand, our present results indicate that catalysts with very low VO x loading are less active due to the dominant VO x species are monomer dispersed. Therefore the dispersion of VO x is the key to control the selectivity and activity of the catalyst. 4.4 RD step and RD states To identify the rate-determining step (RD step) and rate-determining states (RD states) [61,68–71] of the reaction, the Gibbs free energies of the stationary points of the two most energetically favored reaction pathways, i.e. the pathways follow the propyl and propoxide mechanisms on the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface, have been computed. The Gibbs free energy (G T ) of a stationary point at reaction temperature T can be written as(2)G T = E e +ZPE+ΔG 0−T where E e is the potential energy calculated by the DFT method, ZPE is the zero-point vibrational energy and ΔG 0−T is the Gibbs free energy change from 0K to the reaction temperature T. It is noteworthy that for surface reactions, only vibrational modes make contribution to ΔG 0−T and to compute ΔG 0−T all the vibrations are treated as harmonic oscillators. For the complex systems there are a lot of soft vibrational modes. Treating these modes as harmonic may introduce large uncertainty in the computed ΔG 0−T . In addition, some vibrational modes should be treated as hindered or free internal rotations and the physically adsorbed molecules may have more freedoms on the surface. However, accurately treating these vibrational modes is computationally too expensive to be practical for the size of the system studied here. Therefore, computing ΔG 0−T for complex systems is always a very difficult task for theoretical research [72]. Thus, one must bind in mind that the Gibbs free energy profiles presented in the current study may better be treated qualitatively rather than quantitatively. Finally, the Gibbs free energy profiles of the ODP on the OV= site of the dimer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface at 800K are sketched in Fig. 13 . It can be seen from Fig. 13 that the free energy barrier of the first C–H activation step is 53.7kcalmol−1. For the propene formation process, the free energy barrier of the second H abstraction via the propyl mechanism is 15.9kcalmol−1. Alternatively, propene formation from the propoxide intermediate via the propoxide mechanism needs to overcome a free energy barrier of 27.3kcalmol−1. Apparently, it can be concluded that the first C–H activation step is the RD step. Comparing Fig. 13 with the OV=–OV–Ti propoxide pathway of Fig. 9, it can be seen that judging of RD step based on energy barrier must be treated with caution. Considering only energy barrier, the step from IM18 to FS8 via TS16−2 is the RD step. However, since the first C–H activation step and the propene formation step are two different types of reactions that the first one involves a gas-phase propane reactant while the second one is a surface reaction. Directly comparing the energy barriers of the two types of reactions in order to compare the reaction-rate constants of the two reactions is incorrect since for a reaction involving a gas-phase reactant, the large entropy contribution of the gas-phase reactant should not be ignored. Upon adsorption, the three translational motions of the gas-phase reactant (propane in the present study) become three vibrational motions. At the reaction temperature about 800K, the entropy of the translational motions of propane is about 42calmol−1 K−1, which lowers the Gibbs free energy of the reactant by about 34kcalmol−1. According to the transition-state theory, rate constant is determined by Gibbs free energy barrier and one should compare the Gibbs free energy barriers instead of energy barriers. However, does this mean that it is always necessary to perform those expensive vibration analyses in order to compute Gibbs free energy profiles? The answer is no. According to the transition-state theory, the contribution of entropy to the rate constant is through the entropy term [exp(δS/R)] in the pre-exponential factor. It is known that the pre-exponential factors for similar types of reactions have similar values. For example, at 278.15K and 1atm pressure it is around 108 s−1 for the reactions following the Eley–Rideal (ER) mechanism, and is around 1013 s−1 for surface reactions following the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism. Under the typical reaction temperature of ODP on the vanadium-based catalyst about 800K, the pre-exponential factor is around 105 s−1 for the ER-type reactions and around 1013 s−1 for the LH-type reactions. For the whole ODP reaction, the first C–H bond activation step follows the ER mechanism. On the other hand the second C–H bond activation step to form propene can either follow the ER or the LH mechanism. If the reaction follows the propyl mechanism, it belongs to the ER mechanism since the propyl radical is more stable in the gas phase due to its large translational entropy and it will desorb into the gas phase and then react with the surface oxygen centers. If the reaction follows the propoxide mechanism, it belongs to the LH mechanism. If the second C–H activation step follows the propyl mechanism, since both the first and second C–H activation steps belong to the ER mechanism and the entropy of the propyl radical is close to that of propane, the ratio of the two reaction-rate constants is mainly determined by the difference in the two elementary energy barriers. From the potential energy profiles in Figs. 3–9, it can be seen that if the second C–H activation step of the ODP reaction follows the propyl mechanism, the RD step is still the first C–H activation step. On the other hand, if the second C–H activation step of the ODP reaction follows the propoxide mechanism, the situation is a little more complicated. According to the Arrhenius equation: (3) k ER = A ER e − Δ E a ( ER ) / R T (4) k LH = A LH e − Δ E a ( LH ) / R T it can be roughly estimated that at 800K since A ER and A LH are around 105 s−1 and 1013 s−1, respectively. Only if ΔE a(LH) −ΔE a(ER) <29.3kcalmol−1, then the first C–H activation would have a lower reaction rate. The potential energy profiles in Figs. 3–9 indicate that the energy barriers of the second C–H activation step following the propoxide mechanism are all either lower or just marginally higher than those of the first C–H activation step. Therefore it can be concluded that for the ODP on the four catalysts the first C–H activation step is always the RD step. Furthermore, according to the RD state theory of Kozuch and Martin [61], the present computational results also show that the overall energy barrier of the ODP reaction is determined by the relative energy of the TS of the propene formation step respect to the reactant. Therefore, the TS of the propene formation step is the RD–TS. The apparent activation energy of the ODP is then determined to be 29.9kcalmol−1 at 800K. This value is higher than the experimental values measured on the monolayer coverage of supported polymeric V2O5 [22,73]. Our result is qualitatively reasonable since that the apparent activation energy will decrease with the increase of vanadia coverage [14,16]. It should be noted that a direct comparison of the potential energy barrier (without ZPE and thermal corrections as in some previous theoretical studies) for the first C–H bond activation step to the experimental measured apparent activation energy is inappropriate. Although the first C–H bond activation step is the RD step, the energy barrier of the whole ODP reaction is not the same as that of the RD step but the energy difference between the RD–TS and the RD intermediate [61]. In addition, apparent activation energy does not equal to the overall potential energy barrier of the whole reaction pathway. The present results indicate that the overall potential energy barrier for the lowest energy pathway of the ODP reaction is 27.4kcalmol−1. ZPE correction lowers it by 2.4kcalmol−1 and thermal correction raises it by 4.9kcalmol−1 at 800K. The final apparent activation energy at 800K is then 29.9kcalmol−1. From the above discussions it can be seen that for the same type of reactions, it is possible to compare their rate constants through the comparison of their energy barriers. However, due to the uncertainty of the DFT methods in computing energy barriers, ZPE corrections and Gibbs free energy barriers, for those reactions with close energy barriers, an unambiguous determination of the RD step and the reaction pathway followed under the experimental conditions is difficult. To compare the rate constants of the reactions of different types, caution must be taken if the energy barrier of the LH-type reaction is much higher than that of the ER-type reaction. It is important to address here that the rate constant of the ER-type reaction has a stronger dependence on temperature than that of the LH-type reaction. Which step is the rate-determining step is thus temperature dependent. However, since it is the three translational motions that contribute most to the entropy of the gas-phase reactant, we can estimate a threshold for the energy-barrier difference of the LH-type and ER-type reactions at which the rate constants of the two types of reactions are roughly the same at a given temperature. Therefore performing expensive vibrational analyses for all the stationary points is not always necessary and qualitative conclusion still can be drawn from analyzing potential energy profiles but with caution. 4.5 Alteration of reaction mechanism From the discussions above, it can be concluded that the first C–H bond activation step follows a radical mechanism on all the four catalysts. The subsequent activation of the second C–H bond to generate propene follows either a propyl mechanism or a propoxide mechanism on both monomer VO x /TiO2 catalysts. With increasing VO x coverage, on both dimer VO x /TiO2 catalysts, the propene formation step mainly follows a propoxide mechanism. When the VO x coverage reaches to one monolayer (V2O5 crystalline), previous theoretical study [24] suggested that the propoxide mechanism is the only feasible mechanism for generating propene from chemically adsorbed i-propoxide. Therefore, a conclusion can be drawn that the higher coverage of VO x species is, the more possible the propoxide mechanism will be. This is in accordance with previous experimental studies where ethoxide was detected by in situ IR studies of the ODH of ethane [74] and i-propoxide was proposed as the key intermediate for the ODH of propane [14,22,75,76]. 5 Conclusions In summary, we present a comprehensive survey of the ODP reaction over various oxygen sites on the VO x /TiO2 surfaces by periodic DFT methods. Our results are summarized as follows. (i) The first C–H activation of propane belongs to a radical mechanism. OV–Ti exhibits better activity than OV= on the monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) surface while on the monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) surface they exhibit similar activity. On both the dimer VO x /TiO2 (001) and (100) surfaces, OV= is more active. (ii) Propene can be generated via a propyl mechanism or a propoxide mechanism. Both mechanisms are feasible on the two monomer VO x /TiO2 surfaces. However, the propoxide mechanism is preferred on the two dimer VO x /TiO2 surfaces. On all the four surfaces, propene formation on OV–Ti has lower energy barrier. (iii) The activity of the VO x catalysts can be tuned by the TiO2 support surface and the dispersion of the VO x catalysts. Catalysts supported on the anatase (100) surface exhibit higher activity than that on the (001) surface. The tuning of the catalytic activity is through the modification of the bonding ability and nucleophilicity of the oxygen sites. (iv) The first C–H activation step of propane is the RD step and the TS of propene formation process is the RD–TS. A good ODP catalyst requires the cooperation of both terminal and interface oxygen sites for the first and second C–H activation, respectively. coredata.dc:description: The oxidative dehydrogenation of propane (ODP) on the anatase supported vanadia catalysts (VO x /TiO2) have been investigated using periodic DFT calculations. Free energy profiles indicate that the first C–H activation step is the rate-determining (RD) step and the transition state (TS) of the propene formation step is the RD–TS. ODP activity can be tuned by vanadia dispersion and support surface via the modification of the electronic structure of the active oxygen sites. For the RD step, on both dimer VO x /TiO2 catalysts terminal sites have higher activity. On monomer VO x /TiO2 (100) terminal and interface sites exhibit similar activity, while on monomer VO x /TiO2 (001) interface sites have higher activity. With increasing vanadia loading, the formation of propene changes from propyl radical mechanism to a concerted propoxide one. The results suggest that TiO2 (100) is a better support surface. Terminal and interface oxygen sites act cooperatively as the first and second C–H bond activation centers, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: A theoretical investigation on the influence of anatase support and vanadia dispersion on the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propene
